Pope shows ‘slight improvement’ amid special prayers at St. Peter’s VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis remained in critical condition Monday as the Vatican held the first nightly rosary recitation in St. Peter’s Square, underscoring concern over the 88-year-old pontiff’s health. There was some measure of positivity Monday night. The Vatican said that Francis, who has been suffering from double pneumonia, showed “a slight improvement” over the course of the day and after a restful night. He had no further asthmatic episodes, and some laboratory tests had improved, it said. As thousands of people converged on St. Peter’s Square, Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Vatican’s secretary of state, called on prayer to support Francis “in this moment of illness and trial and help him to recover his health soon.” Vatican officials said this was the first time in their recollection that a special saying of the rosary had been held for Francis. Under a steady drizzle, priests, nuns, religious pilgrims and Romans recited the rosary inside the colonnaded square. Cardinals and senior clerics sat at the top of the stairs in front of St. Peter’s Basilica. The altar consisted of a gold-framed depiction of the Virgin Mary cast against the evening darkness under a white canopy. Attendees were somber as they prayed, some visibly moved. “The pope is the most important person in the world for us,” said Wiestow Piosecki, 43, an IT specialist from eastern Poland. He brought his wife and three children to Rome for the jubilee and were devastated when the pope fell ill. “His voice is important, especially with the war in Ukraine. I feel afraid now, afraid he may die. I feel my prayer can help.” Due to the complexity of his clinical picture, the pope’s doctors at Rome’s Agostino Gemelli Polyclinic Hospital were still not prepared to offer a prognosis. In the morning, Francis received Holy Communion, and he worked in the afternoon and was eating solid food. In the evening, he called the parish priest in Gaza whom he has spoken with almost daily throughout the war to offer his “paternal closeness.” Francis, the Vatican said, also offered thanks to those who have gathered in recent days to pray for his health. A mild renal insufficiency disclosed on Sunday, the Vatican said, was not “cause for concern.” The pope’s oxygen therapy continued, although with slightly reduced flows and percentage of oxygen. Francis’s health crisis stretched into the end of its 10th day, making this the longest of his four hospitalizations as pope. Some senior clerics spoke in stark terms over the weekend about his chances. The hospital chaplain said Monday that it was time “to hope against hope.” In recent days, Catholic churches around the globe, including in Francis’s native Argentina, have prayed for the first New World pontiff. On Sunday, Cardinal Baldassare Reina, the vicar general of the Diocese of Rome, held a Mass for the pope, while encouraging other pastors in the diocese to do the same. The saying of the rosary during a papal health crisis is seen as a spiritual gesture to pray for an especially ailing pope. In 2005, Cardinal Leonardo Sandri, then the undersecretary of state for the Vatican, announced the death of John Paul II to the crowds gathered in St. Peter’s Square after they finished saying the rosary for him. Giovanni Maria Vian, a former editor of the Vatican’s newspaper and a historian of early Christianity, said the St. Peter’s event on Monday night for Francis also reminded him of a saying of the rosary before the passing of Pope John XXIII in 1963. “I’m sure numberless such rosaries have been said at Gemelli,” he said. “This [event] feels closer to the prayers in St. Peter’s Square when [John Paul II] and [John XXIII] were dying, back in 2005 and 1963. I was there as a boy, and later [as an adult].” In the upper echelons of the Roman Catholic Church, speculating on the health of a pope has long been delicate terrain. But some senior clerics have offered surprisingly candid assessments. On Saturday, Cardinal Timothy Dolan of New York said, “We’ve got to be kind of realistic. … It’s not looking good.” Francis’s doctors have sought to convey more optimism, suggesting his life is only at risk if he develops serious complications. Talk of his condition is partly due to the pope’s own quest for transparency. His doctors say he has insisted on offering only the “truth” to the public, and the extent of the medical disclosures has been unusual for the Vatican, which is traditionally guarded about a sitting pope’s health. Francis was admitted to the hospital with a respiratory tract infection on Feb. 14. Late Tuesday, the Vatican said CAT scans had revealed the pope to have double pneumonia. Chest X-rays showed he had developed a polymicrobial infection that arose from asthmatic bronchitis and bronchiectasis, a condition in which the airways widen, leading to a buildup of excess mucus that can make the lungs more vulnerable to infection. It said he was undergoing a “complex” treatment using antibiotic cortisone therapy. On Saturday, the Vatican acknowledged in a written bulletin that Francis was in “critical condition.” It added that he had suffered a “prolonged asthmatic crisis” and a low platelet count. He was alert and sitting in an armchair, it said, but suffering more pain than the day before. In a Sunday evening update, the Vatican said the pope’s condition remained “critical” but that there had been no recurrence of the respiratory crisis. He received treatment to boost his red blood cells. Blood tests showed “mild” renal insufficiency but that it was “under control.” The pope, officials said, continued to receive high-flow oxygen through a nasal tube. Cardinal Gianfranco Ravasi marveled at the level of detail being released about a pope’s health. He told Corriere della Sera last week: “It’s remarkable how his conditions have been clearly explained. There used to be a tendency to conceal things related to the [the pope], like the Soviet bulletins in which the secretary had but a cold until he died. Now we go into detail. The ‘polymicrobial infection.’ The ‘bilateral pneumonia.’”
